Naturally, I approved whole heartedly. Before I knew what was happening, they'd spawned it into Tacky Top Tuesdays & Wacky Hat Wednesdays.

I know, right? This IS the funnest coffee shop in town. Seriously, if someone were considering opening their own coffee shop, they would be wise to look to this Peet's (& joints like Mojo on Divisadero) for some tips on building neighborhood repoire.

Yeah, it's a chain. That part is unfortunate. The coffee is consistently solid to very good (some blends I like, some blends I do not like), but always strong enough to power me through the morning. There are closer coffee shops to my office, there are. The reason I keep coming back every day is the people. That's something you can hang your wacky hat on.
author: Pete J.

description: The employees here are really nice and seem to genuinely like what they do. The wait isn't long at all and they are very consistent. This is definitely the place to go whenever I need a pick-me-up at work.
author: Chelsea J.

description: Convenient, nothing special. Service is kind but the setup is sort of cluttered and cramped. There is like this big display right in front of where you would think the line starts, so you have to corral your way through around it. I get frustrated everytime I am in here. But it's close to work and predictable.
author: Greg G.

description:
Although it's been several months since they opened, so glad that Peets opened here. I live here, so there's nothing more special than being able to go downstairs, getting caffeine, and then actually opening your eyes. But the staff here is always great. I get coffee on the way to work every morning and you couldn't ask for anything more...

Wait, I can ask for more. I can ask for the stupid retard customers to actually follow directions and get in the correct side of the line. Idiots.
author: The Sock S.

description:
The following is what I like to call  a "Compliment Sandwich". (Good feedback, negative feedback, good feedback). 

PRO: MUCH better tasting, stronger coffee/espresso drinks than Starbucks.

CON: Where do I line up to order my drink? There's always confusion about where the line begins.

CON: WHY does it take SOOOO much longer to make my latte than over at Starbucks? 
- Archaic as it may seem, Starbucks marks off my drink order with a wax pencil/sharpie ON THE CUP, hands it over to the barista, they make it and have it ready for me before I've gotten to the pick up area. And the process works!
- Peet's spent thousands on a IBM flat screen with the exact drink order electronically sent to you from the register 2 feet away. I mean, my order is on a screen RIGHT IN FRONT OF the espresso machine! Shouldn't you be getting my order before I've even paid? What's the hold up?

PRO: They are open later on Saturday evening (til 8pm?) than Starbucks on 3rd & Howard, so I can get my fix before jumping on the 30 or 45 to go into work.

You do get a 4th star for that one time you were closing, but still let me in, and comped me a cup of drip coffee... Thank you!
author: John Eric S.

description: I f@%#ing hate Peets and its crunchy ass coffee, but last year I saw Dave Chappelle and his bodyguards sitting outside this location enjoying a cup. Apparently Dave feels otherwise #keepingitreal
author: Rebecca S.

description:
Update **4/5/07**
Ok, we're getting closer...Keegan now recognizes me...but she can't remember my name...she says every time, damn, Anne is my sister's name, I should remember it!  Oh well...she knows my drink now.  

****************************************************************************

I really miss my folks at Peet's in Fremont.  But, since I can't take them with me...I had to find a Peet's in the city that works for me.  So, in my effort to maintain my fablous figure, I decided that I would begin a different route this month from Bart to office.  I walk a bit more to get to the office...good for my health and I get to be one of those walkin' caffeine ads...

The new route has me exit at Montgomery and walk to the Peet's 3rd and Mission location.  A bit smaller than my usual in Fremont, you know the burb's, lots of room to s-p-r-a-w-l!   It's nice enough, but they know my name in Fremont.  They know my drink.  How long will it take these Peetsters to get me?  I just want them to get me, that's all I ask.  They make my drink right, perfect in fact.  But they don't know my name.  YET.
author: Anne O.

description:
The folks that work here are nice, I can't complain about the coffee, but my issue with this location is that it's a bit of an organizational clusterfuck. They try different things, but it doesn't seem to work. Without the rope that they occasionally have in front of the counter there to indicate "Hey! OMG! This is the line and this is where you need to stand!" folks seem to get confused. The fact that the space is on the smaller side doesn't seem to help. And the milk/sugar/whatever table is insane. It seems no matter where you stand you are always reaching over someone to get a stirrer, sugar packet, or whatever.  You often need to rotate positions. It's like musical chairs or something.

It also wouldn't hurt if they kept some of the coffee cup sleeves up by the registers. Because that coffee can be dang hot and carrying it just a few feet to the milk/sugar/whatever table is not fun times.

But all that being said, I will continue to get my coffee here pretty much every morning. Because it's like, right there.
author: Tara B.

description:
Ah, yes, a real cup of Peet's - officially brewed rather than mail ordered - for this East Coast boy still sufferin' jet lag after a late arrival last night.

Nice brew + nice scone = nice rating.
author: Scott R.

description: While I have thoroughly enjoyed the flavor of your coffee, as well as the convenience and friendliness of your store since May, your food selection is comprised mainly of unprocessed foods and your salable bananas are constantly green, never yellow. Even Walgreens has better bananas! We're fighting. I'm going back to Starbucks.
author: S W.

description:
Ever gone to a Peet's that has an 80's day? That dresses up for Talk Like A Pirate Day? That transforms the store into Willy Wonka's Chocolate Factory for Halloween, complete with chocolate waterfall? 
I worked at the 3rd and Mission Peet's for about 8 months. Some of the most amazing people I've ever met. Good times!!
author: serra s.

description: It may only be #14 on my visiting order, but 3rd & Mission has always struck me as an ideal Peet's location.  With the museum district on one side and scores of tech startups on the other (including Yelp itself just up the block), who around here *doesn't* need caffeine?  (I myself stopped by to prep for a particularly yawn-inducing session at the Web 2.0 Expo.)  They keep it small enough inside to achieve a modicum of coziness, but alas, the giant pillar in the corner robs you of a real people-watching street view.  Though you can always grab one of the tables on the sidewalk.
author: Wes M.

description:
licking the boots of a full-blown psycho

why do I feel like my smile looks like the cracks in the sidewalk?
why does the sidewalk underneath my feet feel like soda water solidified?
why do your eyes look like headlights anticipating the next corner? (shifty)
 . . .  and I'm a deer prancing to the time out clock?  
why does the sunshine make the buildings look frozen?  
why do I feel like all the pills in the world couldn't make me feel any better about this? (and bottles and cans... full throttle and damned.)
and no one is listening?  no, I'm serious...  it's because I'm stuck?  Thinking of nothing at soundspeed?

Then I get the call.  I don't pick up, of course.
I dial into the mailbox to catch the message in time:

"Boomerang. Sooner than 
you might expect.
In a room or ... man ...  
I don't remember, but it might be insects!"

The sender laughs and hangs up.  Then, she comes on robotically... automatically... gives me the same old options.  

These yelps are getting monotonous.  Went from being over-caffeinated and mentally stagnant with a double-dribbling mouth, to being a roaring.. screaming... unable to open my mouth ...  don't let me begin to tell you about the nightmarish moans from my brain..  
Someone wake me up....   I don't know who I am anymore.

But, still, I never learn.

I walk up to the corner and even if the words don't come out right, they know why I'm here.


"empty stomach large size coffee black."
author: Kenny R.

description: On our way to the Jewish Contemporary Museum and just upon having arrived and parked in the city, we headed over to this Peet's to partake of liquid caffeine yumminess in the guise of one regular mocha for my friend and a white mocha for myself. He also got a slice of cherry chocolate bread and I had a carrot ginger muffin. Definitely yum to both snacks, and the coffee drinks rocked as usual. However, the location doesn't have a restroom available; not a very nice thing to surprise customers with. Also, the order taker was a bit inattentive to my spelling out of the fact that my name begins with an "R" (versus "Brian," utterly annoying since it misses my name by so many letters). Ehh, I'm over it. But, such issues still somehow have to be looked at. Who knows, I might be back at some point.
author: Ryan T.

description:
it is not possible to limn in these few paragraphs my gratitude for this lovely, meticulously clean new peet's, its fantastic, helpful workers and its accessible location from the st. regis hotel as i have seen/spoken to dave chappelle (and his adorable family) not once but TWICE this week. 

for the first minute my mouth, dehiscent as a pod in the spring, couldn't muster words but as he waved my muteness left and volubility returned. practically our entire yelp office flooded in, stephanie to bow at his feet almost in tears, neil and russ to chatter nonchalantly, bran to exclaim, "YOU ARE REAL!" then jess came during promises of visits to the office and proudly handed him a yelp t-shirt.

yes, dave, you're a cool cat, you can just hang out at coffee shops and kick it with all us peons. peet's, i'm glad that i've been buying yelp's coffee from you all this time so it doesn't seem weird that i drop by daily. ;)
author: Ligaya T.

description: I love this particular Peet's. I really like the staff here, and they make me laugh every time. From the sound effects while running the coffee machines to the banter, "Welcome, Are you waking up yet??" , this store is a nice addition to my block. (OK, I live next door.) Also the coffee here is 10x stronger than at starbucks or anywhere else. Possibly even stronger than at other Peet's--talk about ramping up my morning productivity and then also my afternoon productivity.....Phew, 1 small cup gets it done!
author: Meghan O.

description: I may not be first to buy coffee on a Monday morning but I am the First To Review! All hail the new Peet's - opened today.
author: Bob G.

description: It's fifteen minutes faster than the 2nd & Mission Peets.  What's not to love about that?
author: Brandon B.

description: The people here are really nice. The girl remembered my name which for me is a really nice gesture so I will go back here because I appreciate her personal attention to me. Peet's is most definitely way better than Starbucks. Starbucks tastes like mucky sugar water PUH!
author: Morgan M.

description: 1st of all, Peet's Coffee spits on Starbucks... This location is excellent, especially if you're taking a walk to the Metreon, YB Gardens or the Zeum. Minus 1 star for the bum that asked me for .25, dropped the quarter I gave her into her empty cup... then pulled out some real cash to pay for her coffee. I should've got my .25 cents worth and asked her for a sip...
author: Shannon F.

description: Some people like Starbucks. Some people like Peets. Nobody likes both equally. I am definitely a Peets fan!! I will go to Starbucks but only when I don't have a choice and that's the only cafe around. This was my closest Peets when I was working downtown and I remember getting really excited when they first opened. Prior to that the closest one was at least another 5-10 minute walk away which is not as convenient when you want to run out and get back to your office in 15 minutes. Peet's delivers consistently good strong drip coffee. And, I also enjoy their espresso drinks too. It is also great that they can now give you a code for 2 hours of free wifi at their location.
author: Lisa M.

description:
brewing a good espresso is a lost art form.  a latte is more than espresso and milk, and a mocha is more than adding chocolate to a latte.  most places just don't do it right- especially chains.  the exception being peet's.  

if only peet's was actually on my way to work- i'd be here twice a day.
author: Samantha W.

description: I think i'm over coffee forever... being a former starbucks employee.... but peetes is where I go if I cave in. I am not usually into coffee when I walk in, but I LOVE their teas... it's the perfect thing to boost my day. I am two blocks away and I go quite a bit, but there is nothing different about this location than any of the other. I'm afraid peetes is following the sad path of starbucks and making no location different than another... which bores me. Still a good product though... so 4 stars.
author: Preston B.

description: I adore my morning crew! They cater to my picky ass every morning and I love that. The barista's are funny and friendly. If you are a grouchy person that is unable to take a little humor then go to starbucks. This place is not stuck up and pretentious. The coffee is great too!
author: Nicole M.

description: I have to review this Peet's in particular, because this location has consistently friendly staff. It's fantastic! Sometimes, I'll stop by just so I can start my day with a friendly exchange in addition to my hazelnut latte. They are speedy, but never mess up on the orders. Even if there's a line, it goes very fast. All other Peet's should follow this one's example. As much as I like my neighborhood location on Broderick and Fell, all the baristas aren't so nice all the time. I like consistency. This place has got just that.
author: Nina H.

description: Starbucks aficionados STILL whine about how strong Peets is.
author: Eugene G.

description:
This is a busy location. So, if you are looking for a nice quiet location to sit and enjoy your coffee, or a pot of tea with friends, this is not the place. Take a walk down mission towards Embarcadero, you'll find what your looking for on the corner of 2nd. Or, better yet, get out of down town, what are you doing there anyway? Move out of that lawyers way... she's trying to get her second daily dose.

The staff here are wonderful. They make consistently good espresso drinks and they are on top of the Peet's coffee "brewed fresh every twenty minutes" or what have you.  They are friendly, and fast, and most of them have an unbelievable wit. They will make you smile. If you have found otherwise, you probably don't know how to laugh at yourself. Or maybe you are just hurrying along, it's ok, ... I know,  we're all busy. 

However, The crew here give excellent customer service.  And especially excellent service to excellent customers. If you don't know how to be a good customer, here are a few tips:
Decide on your drink before you get to the counter. When you get there, put your damn phone away. Order accurately. You'd be surprised how often I hear patrons (or tourists, or whoever) order their drinks without specifying everything they want. The Peet's crew is listening very carefully to what you say, because they have to enter it into the computer. Believe me, sometimes, you forget to say soy. I know, I am watching from my table in the back, or maybe I am behind you in line. I know. If you are ordering drip coffee, read the notes about the beans they are brewing, or ask. Coffee is like wine, it doesn't all taste the same. If you prefer a nutty, dark chocolate, smoky flavor, make sure the notes on the coffee that day don't say "earthy, with hints of citrus"... or better yet, order a hot chocolate and be done with it. And, please remember when you go into a Peet's... its small, medium, and large. "Can I get a grande latte?" Um, can you go to Starbucks? It's up the street.
author: Erika J.

description:
This newest Peet's in S.F. only gets a 4-star from me, not the 5 I normally give Peet's. Today was their opening day, so of course being a serious Peetnik, I gave it a try. The good news is they are open 7 days a week and they close at 8PM, so if you live in SOMA its probably a shorter weekend walk than the Peet's in the Ferry Building. They are located in the ground floor of the Paramount (I knew I should have bought there) right next to the very sh!tty AG Ferrari. The store looks like most other Peet's, meaning lots of wood, granite, African prints, and generally dark colors throughout. That also means its small on tables (I counted four inside and two or three outside). Not bad by Peet's standard, but it hardly compares to the [cough] Starbucks a few doors away, with their myriad of lounge chairs, coffee tables, and sofas. 
The reason I am subtracting a star, unfortunately, will apply to all Peet's going forward, not just this one. I noticed a new item on the menu: Cafe Freddo Extra Bold. When I asked what "Extra Bold" was, it was explained to me that the standard Cafe Freddo no longer comes with a shot of Espresso, but rather some sort of proprietary "mix". The "Extra Bold" is apparently the old school Cafe Freddo, with an actual shot of espresso. As it should be, I might add. I ordered the "Extra Bold" and it basically tasted as it should. A strong coffee taste, not too sweet. In short, nothing like a Frappucino. But the fact that Peet's has resorted to pulling the espresso from their standard Cafe Freddo is great cause for alarm. Is this the beginning of the "Starbucks-ization of Peet's? Only time will tell...
author: Johnny O.

description: A great place to take a book youve bout and get some nice hot tea and just drink and read. Great service, Clean enviroment, Not too far from places you can go such as the Metreon, Borders, and etc. I suggest the Jasmine Fancy tea, with a nice book. Aside from all this , 2 workers stand out, A guy named Allan, hes very funny and one of the most interesting workers at Peets, and Mandy , a very cute and chill girl. a 5/5 for Peets! Keep up the good work!
author: Jimmy K.

description: What can I say?  I work here.  The staff truly enjoy working here.  We're human and if we mess up just ask.  We'll correct happily.  If you see Allan working, won't you say, "hi!  I saw you on yelp!" ?
author: Doogie H.

description: This is a pretty nice Peet's that's on my way to the office.  As expected, the cashiers / baristas are nice and friendly, and the coffee is definitely up to par.  I was a bit disappointed with their Apple Pastry --- it was a bit dry.
author: Dennis Y.

description: I love Peet's I do. And whenever I have the opportunity I get coffee from a Peet's. But this one is still too new and doesnt give off the vibe one of a kind awesome Peet's vibe I usually see. Also, they have messed up one too many drinks of mine... yet, it's the closest one to my office, so I still keep returning in hopes that it will get better.
author: Lizzie K.

description: I really shouldn't go here before/during work... and since I cant help that I should atleast maybe not order a large. I was in LEGOLAND all day at work today, and based on the current time I'm probably going to need even more coffee tomorrow. Thanks Peet's!!!!!!!
author: katharine s.

description: Hell to the yes ... the world can use more Peet's.
author: Bart C.

description: I have been to this one store a half dozen times now and i have yet to get any kind of decent service.  It has not been uncommon to be the second person in line and have to wait 5 minutes to order. The speed at which these peoeple work is below any coffee shop I have been to.  If you are in a hurry, don't bother with this one.  Hit the one up on the 500 block of mission.
author: Jeff R.

description: I'm more of a tea person. But I like Peet's and I think its worth it to take a second to note that the staff here is extremely friendly, quick and were very cool to a homeless guy who got on his knees to beg for coffee/money. The guy kept his cool and treated dude with respect, the dude was scary but he dealt with it in a calming way that didn't make me panic. Impressively handled.
author: Jackie B.

description: When I come to Peet's I get the simple stuff.  The simpler the better. It means: coffee beans.  They have all kinds of coffee beans to choose from.  I buy them and brew good coffee at home.  The coffee they make is not bad, although not outstanding either.  The holiday soy latte is too sweet, and the green tea soy latte is disgusting.  They have no matcha powder, so they'd drop the green tea tea bag inside steamed soy milk...I don't blame them.  Most coffee shops don't have matcha powder.  With the good selections of coffee beans, Peet's still my man.
author: Vivian H.

description: I love the green tea & the people who work here. They're very chill.
author: David Z.

description: That's pretty damn lame of you to rate a place simply because a celebrity was seen there. Therefore, I give this Peets a retalitory 1 star. If I could rate individual contributors, y'all would each also get 1 star. Thank you.
author: C S.

description: i love this location, in fact it's the only one i will ever go to. main reason: the boys who work there are drop dead gorgeous - particularly the one with the green eyes.
author: Marit K.

description:
Hi, I used to work at the 3rd & Mission Street Peet's location and I really miss it.

I hope at least one of my old regulars reads this...

I miss you Hellen!
I miss you Ellen.
I miss you Niel, with your yellow Marmot fleece.
I miss you guy who always got Lemon Rose hot tea.
I miss you Ross the boss, best construction worker ever.
I miss you Hector!
I miss you Alan, with the really cool daughter.
I miss you Curtis who brought me wine for my birthday.
I miss you Mr. Medium Decaf with the owl specs.
I miss you grumpy Jeff, always in a hurry.
I miss you Large Latte Kelly
I miss you Shane
I miss you Tappin
I miss you Cappy
I miss you Scott! I wish you hadn't moved away
I miss you 3 times a day Todd
I miss you Barry medium add shot!
I miss you Kaitlyn with the purple streak in your hair
I miss you mystery man with the nice beard that I always gave free drip to
I miss you medium drip David!
I miss you Frank, probably the most of all.
I miss you Wendy, I wish I still saw you every morning.
I miss you Marge, even though I know that isn't your real name
I miss you princess, even though I KNOW that isn't YOUR real name.
I miss you Dan Dan the Tax Man, Medium drip for here
I miss you Carole
I miss you Judith, medium half caff.
I miss you Charlie with the rasta hat and painted nails.
I miss you vegan scone and Iced coffee Stacey
I miss you Jamal! 
I miss you Awet
I miss you big man with the same Woody Allen glasses as me
I miss you Shannon who always complimented my clothes and asked about my art.
I miss you gunpowder Barbara.
I even miss you, very small man who asked for a sample every single day that I worked there.

I really do miss you all and I hope at least one of you reads this and realizes how awesome you are because the customers at my new store aren't even worth remembering their names (Except for you, Thelma and Mark, if you're reading this). None of them are as friendly or nearly as interesting as you. You were an honor to share my mornings with and I probably took for granted the fact that you weren't mean to me like my new customers are. Thank you for being patient and sincere. Thank you for adding to the bank of things I know and telling me stories I appreciate even now. 

I know this sounds cheesy, but I miss you. I hope you're taking care of the  staff at 3rd & Mission.
author: Brynn B.
